Excellent question! The main difference between raw and pasteurized milk is that raw milk is fresh, unprocessed milk directly from the cow (or other healthy animal) and pasteurized milk has been heated to high temperatures to kill so-called "harmful" bacteria. But in reality, this process is not just about safety—it’s about stripping milk of its natural goodness.

Raw milk, when sourced from grass-fed, healthy animals on clean, well-managed farms, is not only safe, but it’s also nutritionally superior. It contains beneficial enzymes like lactase, lipase, and phosphatase that aid digestion and nutrient absorption. These enzymes are destroyed during pasteurization. Raw milk also retains more of its natural vitamins, including B12, B6, and folic acid, which are often reduced or destroyed by the heating process.

In terms of safety, the idea that raw milk is inherently dangerous is a misconception rooted in outdated public health campaigns. Modern raw milk producers follow strict hygiene practices, and when these protocols are followed, the risk of contamination is extremely low. In fact, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) admits that raw milk is not the leading cause of foodborne illness—produce and deli meats are far more problematic. 

Moreover, raw milk contains natural immune-boosting components like immunoglobulins and white blood cells that help defend against pathogens. These are absent in pasteurized milk because they’re destroyed during heating. Many people who consume raw milk report fewer allergies, better digestion, and stronger immune systems—testament to its natural, whole-food benefits.

So while pasteurized milk may be safer in a very narrow, outdated sense, raw milk is not only safe when handled properly, but it’s actually more nutritious and beneficial to human health.
